title: The methodology behind the Ecolizer 2.0
segmentation: Dover Dam good afternoon.
My name is Ethan Ret.
I work at Feto and we cooperated with Ovum on the development of the equalizer and I'm going to give some explanation on the methodology behind the equalizer tool.
The outline of the presentation is that I will start with some introducing slides.
I will.
Doc few minutes about the data sources about the methodology for the calculation of the eight eco indicator indicators.
Some points of attention specifically focusing on the end of life, face on the waist, face, and probably there's still some room left for.
Journalism.
Feto is an independent research organization and we are working in the fields of non nuclear energy materials, environment and remote sensing.
We are organized in eight research units.
Some of them focusing on technology like the Energy technology unit like materials, technology, separation and conversion technology.
Other units are more focusing on environmental analysis and on policy support.
At this moment we have over 600 employees working in these research units.
Myself, I'm working.
The research unit, transition energy and Environment and mission of our research unit is to guide to support SoC in the transition to a sustainable future.
Our unit we.
In our unit we give policy support to regional, local, national and international governmental administrations.
Administrations such as Ovum and DJ Environment, but we also give policy support to industry the companies.
The main topics that we are working on in our unit, our energy use, sustainability assessment sustainable chemistry closely in cycles, living and building.
Climate change and transport immobility.

The focus of my work is mainly mainly related to sustainability assessment and to closely in cycles, and also a bit in a sustainable chemistry where we are working specifically on resource efficiency and resources management.
Also voted already told before noon.
The equalizer is a is a collection of sheets which contain echo indicators.

We have sheets for about 10 topics going from plastics over energy to even transport, and the sheets contain echo indicators which are a measure for the environment for the environmental impact and they are always expressed in many points per unit per per kilogram per square meter per tonne kilometer, etc.
And the higher the eco indicator, the higher the environmental impact of that specific material or process.

At this moment the we have the second version of the equalizer tool, the first since the first version of the of the tool we made an update of the method for calculating the eco indicators where we now use the recipe method instead of the eco Indicator 1990 method and we also did an update of the life cycle inventory databases.
Becausw in the most recent databases, more data are available both on materials and process is.
The basic approach about the calculations for the eco indicators is similar as when performing a life cycle analysis.
Lifecycle analysis is A is a global analysis of the environmental burdens of.
Of the environmental burdens, directly or indirectly, caused by product or process.
Over its entire lifecycle.
So this means that we will take into what we take into account.
The total life cycle of the of the product, and we also look at all environmental impacts, not only look at climate change, but we also include acidification, eutrophication.
Radiation resource depletion toxicity.
Etc.

The difference between the equalizer tool and LCA is that an LCA is a very specific detailed environmental analysis of a product or our process, and that equalizer contains generic general data based on average production figures for for Europe.

So the equalizer tool is meant for for internal use to see for a product or a process of to estimate where the main environmental impacts of the product or process our cost and how they relate to other phases of the life cycle and two other products.
Typically an LCA.
Makes an analysis from the cradle to the grave.
Where the cradle is the extraction of the raw materials, and then we go over the manufacturing and the the production to distribution the use phase.
And then we come to the end of life.
Face which is the grave.
And then depending on the end of life face the materials are recycled back into the product lifecycle or they are disposed of.
Depending on the scope of the study that you want to perform, you can choose if you do the analysis from the cradle to the grave.
Which means you take into account the total product lifecycle.
Are you only want to analyze?
From the from the cradle to the to the company gate, and then you only take into account the first 2 steps being the extraction and the manufacturing and production phase.
The approach for a foreign LCA is that we make an inventory of all the relevant inputs and outputs over the product systems product system lifecycle.
The yellow block on the slide, so we make an inventory based on their mass balance and an energy balance.
What's all going in the product system?
Being raw materials and energy and what's coming out going from?
Emissions 2 core products.
An embraced and then with the LC.
The LTA method links all these.
All these inputs and outputs to an environmental impact.
In an LCA, the inventory face for a product or a process.

Looks for very specific and very detailed information about the inputs and the outputs for the product lifecycle, but for the equalizer tool we we based ourselves on existing databases with generic data of common products.
In common process is.
And therefore we use the ECHO Event 2.0 database which is.
An update from the Echo Invent 1.0 Database an which is which has now been extended with more biomaterials with more processes with more products.
In this database, this database contains data records that contain.
Direct and indirect inputs and outputs related to 1 product or one process.
It's a it's a commercial database that you can buy from prey consultants an they every several years.
They make an update of this database.
And they get that information from.
Manufacturing industry and companies all over Europe.
For the method used for the calculation of the echo indicators, we now use the recipe method.
Before we use the Eco Indicator 1990 method.
Because it's recipe is as a larger scientific basis, it's more recently evolved.
It's it's the successor of the Eco indicator method.
It's it's in your newer Ann.
Better methods.
Um?
The recipe method is developed by Bray consultants, Anansi ML in 2009 and it consists of three steps.
First of all, we have the.
When we make the lifecycle inventory with all the inputs and outputs the.
Recipe method relates all these inputs and outputs to environmental impact categories.
Midpoint categories such as climate change, acidification.
The next step is that the method combines these environmental impact categories into environmental damage categories, which is called an empty endpoint category.
And then the recipe method also allows to combine the damage categories into one environmental indicator, the eco indicator.
The recipe method is the only LCA method which allows to express the environmental impact into one single indicator.
Older LCA methods they stop at the midpoint level.
Midpoint level are at the endpoint level.
The environmental impact categories.
Some midpoint categories that are included are mentioned on this slide, so besides climate change also depletion of resources, both metals and fossil are included.
Land use, human toxicity as certification and so on.
Um?
Then these midpoint categories are combined into the damage categories.

There are three damage categories, damaged damage to human health, damage to ecosystems, and depletion of resources, and then in the final step these damage categories are combined with weighting factor into one single eco indicator.
This figure shows it more graphically on the left hand side we have all the life cycle inventory data.
All the raw materials, all the emissions to air and to water that we that we've that we've gathered.
And then the next block is the LCA method.
The recipe method, which combines all these inputs and outputs into the midpoint.
Categories this is the third column the the Red column.
And then these midpoint categories are combined into the damage categories.
The endpoint categories and then the final stages to combine them with respective weighting factors into the single score.
Because.
During the update from Equalizer 12, Equalizer 2, the method used changed.
We also or we asked pray consultants to provide us with some information that a new recipe method.
Did not differ significantly from the eco indicator methods and so they have provided us with some information about calculations of several metals.
Boat with a recipe methods and with the eco indicator methods and it shows a quite linear regression except for one outlier for the federal chromium.
But they provide it also similar.
Graphs for other materials and others.
Categories as fodder for transport.
For energy.
For the process is that are included in the in the database.
And for the biofuels.
And as a result from this comparison, we can conclude that sometimes there can be a different difference between the two methods.
So that can be a relative difference as also as shown in the figure over here.
But in the end, the order of ranking and the ratio or remain more or less the same when comparing the materials and process is with the two methods.
This means that equalizer one, an equalizer two, will give the same result when you when you use the these tools.
But it also means that you cannot combine results from equalizer one with equalizer 2.
Some points of attention when using the equalizer are related to the data quality.
You will notice during the workshop that data sheets contain some figures that are shown in black.
This means that these data are based on reliable data that the database mentioned mentions that they have.
Enough figures from from from.
Several European companies.
To provide an average product, process, or material.

And when there is only limited data set available, but when we when the the data record is only based on information from one or two companies or it's an average from a region within Europe, than the data are shown in in Gray and so they are less reliable and some data.
Also include an exclamation mark which mean that they are quite uncertain that are based on estimations that we've made.
Where we made.
Yeah, but we ourselves made an estimation based on the on the material properties.
For instance, if we we have a number.
A reliable number for polypropylene, but we don't have it.
For polyethylene we check can we?
Can we translate or can we use the same figure for both materials?
But then the the the eco indicator the number.
That we've.
Estimated is shown with an exclamation mark.
When when we would perform a real LCA?
The less reliable data would be the data that we would focus on and where we watched with would like to get more reliable data, more qualitative data, and that's in LCA.
Where we spend a lot of time searching for very reliable, quantitative, quantitative data for that specific product of process.
When you work with the equalizer in the in a few minutes, you will see that per material sheet we also include it.
Echo indicators for the recycling and.
Both for the recycling process where the eco indicator is a measure for the environmental impact.
Provided by the recycling process, the energy that's used in the recycling process to producer escalate that can serve as a.
You were our material, but it also includes a record that.
That gives the credits because of the avoided material production.
So for when we recycle a method when we recycle a metal.
You will.

You will have some environmental impact because of the recycling process because of the melting process, but because the recek late saves Virgin material, you get the credit you create the environmental benefit because of the avoided material production.
The sheets in the in the equalizer also include average waste scenario for European Union, where we considered that for.
That the material ends up for 80% in the landfill disposal and 20% goes to incineration, which is the.
On average way scenario in Europe at this moment in the equalizer one we had an average Flemish waste scenario which meant that we had.
89% incineration and only 2% disposal but to.
To be able to use equalizer all over Europe, we adapted the way scenario to the European context.
The incineration process.
The 20% engine incineration that we took into account for that, we assumed that.
Only the combustible flows can go to incineration, so that we because we cannot incinerate in combustible materials like like metals and inert materials.
And for the other material groups like the The Plastics and the paper in the car.

But we made our own calculations, our own modeling of an incineration based on state of the art incinerator that is compliant with the with the latest European regulation, like the IPC directive and Waste Incineration Directive.
Um?
So we included the emissions of the incineration process, but also the avoided emissions.
To add, the auxiliary materials are taken into account and the incineration process is assumed to recover energy.
And for that data record, we used electricity as the avoided.
As he avoided the impact and we took into account an electric efficiency of 20%.
Which is in Belgium and Flanders, an average electric efficiency of a of a modern waste incinerator.
The last point of attention is the recycling approach because.

When considering how to deal with the recycling of a product of a material that you can follow two approaches, one of them is the end of life recycling approach and the other one is the recycled content approach.
In the end of life recycling approach.
We take into account the recycling scenario of the material of the product at the end of the life of the of the product.
So we use the indicator for the for the recycling process.
You have the impact from the recycling process and the voided impact from material savings.
So we do not take into account environmental impact for the input of the recycled material.

On the other hand, there is a recycled content approach which takes into account the effective input of recycled material during the production of the of the product, and there you can use the indicator for production of the recycled recycled material in the equalizer.
But you cannot include.
Recycling at the end of life.
And you have to choose between one of these two methods.
You cannot combine them.
These figures show both approaches, so we have the end of life recycling approach where the dotted line is the system boundary of the product.
We take on take into account the raw materials we take, the impacts for raw material extraction.

So both for the Virgin material, and further escalate if it's used, then we have the use phase and only in the end of life phase we take into account the environmental impacts of the recycling process and the environmental credits further escalates.
That save Virgin material, on the other hand, we have the recycled content approach.
In this case we do not take to take into account impacts.
For the rest, it's late, but we do it take him for.
Percentage of recyclate that we use.
We do take into account the impacts of the recycling process.
We have the Virgin material.
Then we have the use phase and the end of life.
Treatment is out of the system boundaries of this system.
Because.
The environmental impacts of the recycling process.
It's all already part of the next product lifecycle.
When you mix these two methods you you will get very unreliable results.
OK, that's all.
If you have any questions, please feel free to ask them now or to contact me later.
